headline: Pizza Crust
description: This pizza crust recipe quickly makes the easiest pizza dough with one bowl, 6 ingredients, and no kneading required for delicious homemade pizza.

video.description: See how to make easy homemade pizza dough.
video.name: Pizza Dough III

name: Pizza Crust
recipeIngredient: 1 cup warm water (110 degrees F/45 degrees C)
2 cups bread flour, plus more for dusting

recipeInstructions.text: Dissolve yeast in warm water in a small bowl. Let stand until creamy, about 5 minutes.

Combine bread flour, olive oil, sugar, salt, and yeast mixture in a mixing bowl; stir well to combine. Beat until a stiff dough has formed. Cover the bowl; let rise at room temperature until dough doubles in volume, about 30 minutes.
Preheat the oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
Turn dough out onto a well-floured surface. Form dough into a round and roll out into a thin crust. Cover with your favorite sauce and toppings.
Bake pizza in the preheated oven until cheese is bubbly and crust is golden brown, about 20 minutes.

review.reviewBody: Following the comments of others, I do add more flour sometimes up to a cup more. This is our go to recipe for pizza crust
Awesome
simple and good
I have my Family and Consumer Science students use this recipe for pizza labs. They love it, and so do I! I use it at home too! Fantastic recipe.
Very tasty! My family loved it, as it was fluffy like focaccia.

Easy. Fast. Fun. Need to learn how to better distribute the dough...tad think in the middle! Use cornstarch on your pizza stone or tray if you want it a bit "crunchier" and up the temperature on the stove, at 350 the dough was still "white" and doughy...changed it to 400 and it finally looked and tasted more like "real" pizza. FLOUR = 880 OIL = 240 SUGAR = 40 TOTAL CALORIES = 1160

Required some changes. Baked it on 400 and it was still soft on the bottom, so it would probably be better to bake it on 425-450 to get the base crisp that way I like it. I added garlic powder, 1/2 tsp more salt, and 1/4 + 2 tbsp of flour when kneading it.

The only think I did differently was add a sprinkle of Italian seasoning into the mixture. Dough came out great, spread out very easily with a rolling pin and most importantly, tasted really good (even cold the next day!) I saw someone commented that it came out really wet & sticky and they had to add more flour - I watched the video - when it's removed from the bowl, it's put on a surface with lots of flour on it. I did just that and folded the dough into the flour a bit and it was perfect when I went to spread it out with the rolling pin.
It was really fast. Plus, nobody told me I could make a crust shape. I loved it!
This is a great simple pizza dough! I make my own sauce to go on with toppings . I like to make mini versions for my grandson. One of his fav foods.

Best pizza I ever made. Dough is simple and easy. I added a dash of Italian seasoning to dough and used whole wheat flour for dusting. Baked plain crust for 3 minutes to set then pulled from oven and added toppings. Sauce in 2 layers, first then after half the cheese.
Very easy and good
perfect pizza crust, ty vm

This was super easy and tasted great.. it's a keeper. I did grease my pizza pan with a tsp of olive oil and sprinkles corn meal lightly on it before putting dough on the pan. This really makes a large pizza so if your pan is not very large, use half and make two pizza if you don't like thick crust.
This dough is way too soft. You have to pour it. Makes a spongey crust.
My go-to pizza dough recipe. I like to use garlic infused oil. An absolute banger!
This was a mess! The ratio didn’t turn out right at all- took a full cup of extra flour.

This is my pizza dough recipe. That's not to say I wrote it or can in any way take credit for its creation. Rather, this is the recipe I use to make pizza any time I make it. It is simple, tasty, and reliable. It is one of the very first recipes I got from this site and, if my stained and crumpled printout is to believed, I have been using it since 2013.

Of course, I have my own little tweaks and adjustments (don't we always):

- I follow the ingredients list and measurements as written but usually make 1.5 the default volume to get two decent sized pizzas. 

- I also make the dough in a stand mixer and knead with the kneading hook for about 10 minutes minimum to get the dough nice and springy before rising. I add quite a bit of extra bread flour as it kneads (1/2 cup to over a whole cup depending) because the dough is quite wet and sticky as written and I want to be able to handle it.

- I use a pizza stone and peel rather than a pan and start the oven heating to 500°F while the dough is rising. Use lots of cornmeal on the peel to keep the dough from sticking and bake for 8 minutes directly on the stone in the middle of the oven.

Great Pizza dough. Add toppings of light olive oil, pesto & garlic cream, light blend of shredded cheeses, olives, mini cut tomatoes, pepper rings with onion/mushroom caramelized. A butter/garlic salt/cayenne pepper coating for the crust near the end of cooking! All dressed hit !!!

Hands down my favourite pizza dough recipe. Took a couple times to figure out how thick to roll out the dough. But that’s a preference thing. I prefer to make pizzas at home with the recipe over delivery!

1-WILL NEVER BUY grocery store bought pizza dough again
2-SUPER EASY to make
3-TASTE is high quality
4-USE ONLY bread flour (and don't substitute anything AND follow exact instructions; plan ahead people!)
5-TIP #1: ADD EXTRA 1/2 cup bread flour to recipe. Dough is still a bit sticky/moist
6-TIP #2: LET RISE for 1-2 hours (put in med/large bowl and throw a tea towel on top)
7-TIP #3: Use generous flour on pizza peel/large cutting board to roll out dough
8-TIP #4: I baked a thin crust large pizza at 450 degrees for 17 mins

this recipe is amazing. at first I was wary about not kneading the dough but there was no need to worry. I got my trusty hand held wire pizza dough whisk out and I just could not believe how fast this came together. I made my pizza using this recipe and honestly it is probably the best crust recipe ever. Thank you!!!

Tried this dough by following instructions to the T! This came out wonderful! I made a double batch and let it rise, I took 1/4 for a small pizza for my daughter, and took the rest and placed on a square baking sheet. I let it rise again for 10-15 minutes, then topped and baked at 450 until golden. Family loved it! Thanks!!
Added yeast to make it rise more....otherwise it's good.....best I have found so far! Even my wife loves it!

An excellent dough compared to others I’ve tried. Simple and easy. However it definitely takes more flour than called for. It needed an extra half a cup or so. Result is excellent. Made it 4 times so far, all very good.
delicious! MMMMMMMM
fluffy and delicious. Makes enough dough you could separate into to pizzas
Came out perfectly! Just added the 1/2 extra cup of bread flour suggested by another reviewer.
This dough actually tastes like clay. It has zero flavour. Add spices or use another recipe.

Made this for the first time last weekend (and it was my first time ever making any sort of dough from scratch, so it was quite the learning experience). It came out really good in the end. I used a Kitchenaid mixer with a dough hook to mix the dough initially. The dough was quite sticky and wet after adding the called-for amount of flour, so I added about another quarter to half cup in 1-2 Tbsp increments until it wasn't so sticky. Rolled it up and placed it in a lightly oiled bowl and let it sit for about 2 hours at room temperature. Punched it down and let it rise another hour. Cut it in half, and stretched it out into two roughly 12" (average) sized crusts. This was the difficult part for me, as it was like trying to stretch out a rubber band. The crusts didn't really want to stay put much, but after letting them sit for several minutes between stretchings they were about the size I wanted. The crust got very thin in places, and tore in a few more, but after pinching the tears back together and baking, the crust was a perfect thickness throughout. I baked the pizzas in a Kamado charcoal grill at about 800 degrees at the top of the dome, and around 550 at the pizza stone, using a few chunks of apple wood to give them a bit more of a wood-fired flavor. They came out excellent. Crispy throughout with a bit of chewiness at the very center. The outside of the crusts were light and airy, with just the right amount of crispiness.
Needs more like 2 1/2 to 3 cups of flour.
This is the best pizza dough recipe I've tried. I'll never buy pre-made again

I added the sugar to yeast and warm water to proof, put dry ingredients together, stirred in oil into yeast mixture before adding to dry ingredients. After dough formed covered with a little bit of oil let stand in bowl with towel over it for 45 minutes. Then used. Yes Iike this recipe made this way best

Easy and made for a good chewy dough. We found it difficult to form pizza form, but overall good tasting. The second time I added herbs to dough and. Let rise for longer than stated. Better second time.
I absolutely love this recipe. It always comes out great. Though, I do add some Italian Seasoning and garlic powder for flavor, it is perfect.

I made this dough today. I used bread flour, took the temp of the water for the yeast, let rise for over an hour yet my dough never rose. I was skeptical but moved forward, rolled it out and pre baked it for 5 min at 425. Then, I added my ingredients and cooked an additional 20 min at 425. The dough came out crispy and my husband said it's one of the best pizzas I've made. So, even though it didn't rise, it was still a success. 
Note, the only change to this recipe was the oven time. Otherwise, followed everything else exact. It was very good and I would make again.

I doubled the recipe and added 2 additional tsps sugar to the warm water/yeast mixture. I also increased the olive oil from the specified 1/2 cup to 1/3 cup. After the pie was removed from the oven I brushed the crust with melted butter and then sprinkled the crust with garlic powder and garlic salt. The results were awesome and my family loved it!

This recipe definitely made some decent pizza dough. I didn't change the ingredients and cooked the pizza for the recommended amount of time....but it kinda tasted like a non-frozen Digiorno pizza rather than fresh pizza. It didn't taste bad, but I was very underwhelmed.

My 9 year old picky eater said our pizza tasted better than take out! I did only add 3/4 cup water and added garlic powder, rosemary and Italian seasoning (about 1/2 tsp each) and it was delicious! I also baked the crust for 8 mins at 400 before adding sauce and toppings.
Deep pan ham and mozzarella yummy came out great for a first try.

I have made this dough a number of times now and have loved it! It was my very first attempt at ever making my own pizza dough and it turned out perfect every time - including the very first time! I have made it substituting the olive oil with coconut oil, simply because I didn't have olive oil on hand the first time. Still turned out great! I have used bread flour and also unbleached all purpose flour - both ways turned out great! I have never added the sugar. I do tend to use more flour than the recipe calls for, probably 1/4-1/2 cup - I haven't actually measured, I just add till I get a nice consistancy that isn't sticky. Our typically takes closer to 30 min to bake to our liking.

Such a great recipe, super easy and delicious! We added rosemary and oregano to the dough and let it rise in an oiled pan for an hour. We also brushed the dough with olive oil before putting it into the oven. A complete and total hit with my husband...and hes a baker by profession!

Making it for the second time right now! I divided it into two balls to make thin crust pizzas. Turned out perfect. This has been added to my favourites! *tip, I needed a little additional flour to make the dough less sticky, don’t be afraid to add some a sprinkle at a time to get a consistency easy to work with.*
Very easy recipe, make it several times a month. I find doing it by hand does a far better job on the final product!
I made this yesterday and it turned out very well. The dough was super easy to make. I didn't have bread flour, so I used all-purpose, organic flour.

Its a quick and easy recipe, however, I suggest you add about 1/2 cup to 3/4 cup more flour to your recipe and a tsp garlic powder for added flavor. Dough is very wet and hard to manipulate so you will need grease your hands and dust dough often to be able to manipulate it onto the pizza pan and form. But it’s was fun making it with my son.
Easy to make
This dough is so yummy and easy. No more take-out for me!
I thought the recipe was good but I did change it up a bit. Used a bit more oil and once it was proofed, I wrapped it up in Saran Wrap and let sit for a day in the fridge.
Yes it was easy and will make again.
Very good dough. Easy to work with. I always add sauce to my dough and bake for 10 minutes (or 1/2 the bake time) prior to adding toppings.

Good but not nearly enough flour. I added almost a full extra cup of flour. Also added a little basil to the dough. Used it for a white pizza. Baked at 375 for about 8 minutes before putting toppings on, then baked another 15. At the end I slid the pan out from under it and cranked up the heat to crisp the bottom up a bit more. Turned out really good
Excellent
Terrible, won't make it again
The dough is easy to make and it tastes amazing . Thank you !!

This was good. It has been a long time since I’ve last made pizza dough so I’m basically a newbie. I read some reviews first so I knew the dough was going to be pretty sticky. I threw a bit more flour in as I was hand kneading and it was better. Still sticky but I didn’t know what to really expect. I let it rise near a heat vent for around 45 min and then had it in the fridge for about 3 hours (was planning on making tomorrow) It really rose beautifully and I decided to have it for lunch. The reason I didn’t give it 5 stars Is because I followed a reviewer and changed my temp to 400 as opposed to the instructions’ 350. 400 was good, the middle wasn’t soggy but it was still softer than I would have liked. The rest of the dough was fluffy and chewy and delicious. I also added 1/2 tsp each of garlic powder and Italian seasoning.

Good pizza doesn't exist in Guatemala, but it does in my house, thanks to this crust. My hubby and I struggle because he likes his crust thick, and I like it thin. He likes lots of veggies and I like sausages, pepperoni and spicy. For a fraction of the cost of chain store pizzas here, we can have both. 

I just follow the recipe. I do add Italian seasoning to it, because I like it, but otherwise, and unusual for me, I just use the recipe. I have tried others that are either too soft or too stiff, but this one raised perfectly, went into a cookie sheet on parchment paper very well, and cooked up beautifully. I topped it with good ham, fresh pineapple, onions and peppers. I was feeding hungry men, and luckily I got one piece. Thank you for this terrific recipe!! I will be making this much more often.
Tasty but a very thick crust. Too thick for my liking - but maybe good for others.

A good quick recipe. 
Sub'd barley malt syrup for the sugar to give the crust more flavor (best way is a starter the night before ). It's a staple in Bernard Clayton's Italian bread recipe.
Everyone here loved it even though I used regular flour. As others mentioned, I had to use extra flour to get the consistency needed though.
I made it for the first time tonight and it was great
I made it for the first time tonight and it was great
worst pizza crust, didn’t rise and tasted like cardboard.......
I made it exactly per the recipe, just let it rise a little longer. It turned out great.
easy and fast
I used 1c. all-purpose flour, 1c. bread flour, reduced the oil to 1T, sugar to 1t. and salt to 1/2t.

I do love the simplicity of this recipe, it was one the first I tried when I ventured into making my own pizza. What I did have to adjust was the oven temp once the pizza went in. 350 is just not hot enough to cook it properly. 400 works perfectly. But other than that........it's awesome!!! Give it a go and you won't be disappointed!!

I've been on a quest to find the "perfect" pizza dough (for us.) If you're short on time, this is it. I used my KitchenAid stand mixer and yes, it's a very wet, sticky dough. I added one more tablespoon of (bread) flour and decided to just see how it would turn out. A dough this hydrated can be incredibly intimidating if you're not used to working with it (dough.) I let mine rise covered, on the stovetop and it rose beautifully. I turned it out onto a fairly heavily floured surface and gave it a few folds. I did it both by hand and with a bench scraper. Next time, I'm going to forgo the floured surface and use a lightly oiled surface. I divided in half and cooked in 2, preheated, screaming-hot, cast iron skillets (500 degrees for preheat and 475 for cooking.) I cooked about 12 minutes and both were excellent. Brown and fry-crisp on the bottom but fluffy on the inside. To make the rounds I, cut in half and then used my fingertips (like making a focaccia) to get it into shape. Light stretches on the outer edges and it was perfect. I let it rest about 15 minutes and it developed a lot of nice bubbles. When transferring to the hot skillet, you have to commit to the move!!! (I used 10 inch skillets) or use a HEAVILY floured peel/parchment sheet. I added about 1 TPBS to the hot pan and added my toppings quickly. 
We'll be using this recipe for weeknights or last minutes pizza decisions when I haven't planned ahead. 
*NOTE* I've tested Bobby Flay's pizza dough, ATK 2 day pizza dough

I've made this dough a few times for either stuffed breads or pizza. I agree with others that it comes out too sticky and pulls apart easily. It's better to reduce the oil to 1 tbsp and to add flour for better strength. It's good, otherwise...

Great and easy recipe!! I ended up doubling the recipe to make 2 pizzas. Would recommend increasing the temperature of the oven (depending on your oven), i ended up having to leave them in for longer than 20 minutes.

I’ve been making this dough for about 8 years and love it! We do add a bit of spices because we prefer the taste. The key is in proofing the yeast. I’ve never had trouble with the dough getting done, but just realized in rereading this that I’ve always baked it on 400! It works great for some nice Italian rolls to go with pasta also. Just pinch off pieces, roll them in butter and bake them in a muffin tin. Or shape them, let them rise about 15 min. and brush with butter after baking.

This isn’t a very good recipe. Ive made a lot of bread and different doughs before. I made the dough just as said and even added a little more flour. Still way to sticky and didn’t turn out very well.
Easy to make and even better than fresh dough from the grocery store. Will definitely be making this again.

This was super easy to make and very tasty. I followed the recipe as is, I took the advice from a previous rating and cooked it at 400 for 20 mins or so. I also used a pizza stone. Between those two things, I had no problems with soggy dough, it was perfect.
The perfect crispy fresh pizza dough recipe! The only difference is I followed the yeast package for how much water to add, then I just adjusted according the get the end result.

This was every bit as good as the best reviews said, but it did also require the modifications mentioned in many reviews. I made this using my stand mixer and kept gradually adding flour because it was so sticky. I added between an extra 1/4 and 1/2 cup. I also added garlic powder and Italian seasoning, which ended up tasting amazing. I let rise for about 45 minutes to allow it to double and baked it (no prebake) at 400 for 20-25 minutes on a vented pizza pan. I brushed garlic butter on the edge of crust during the last 5. Will definitely make again.
Flavorless, boring pizza dough. Literally 7x the amount of yeast needed for proper pizza dough. Should use white slices of bread as substitute for same effect.
Added a little extra flour until it felt right. Turned out great.

I used truvia nectar (stevia with honey and sugar) and Wesson canola oil. I also added onion and garlic powder and Italian seasoning. I turned the oven on for three minutes then turned it off and put the covered bowl in. Let it rise about thirty minutes. Preheated the baking sheet a few minutes. Then let it bake for 15. I needed a bit of flour on my hands to roll it out. It was sticky. I loved it! Fluffy crust with just a bit of crispiness. Best I’ve made and will make again.

I love this base. I cut the dough into three different portions which are a perfect size for an individual pizza. I then use a basting oil for the crust, jarred sauce with added basil, and fresh mozzarella cheese with oregano.

I add the sugar when activating the yeast but other than that small change followed the recipe. I think the oven temperature is too low when you consider real pizza ovens run at 700-800 F. I use a pizza stone and max out the temperature in my oven (550 F).

decided to use brown sugar just to see... and oiled the edge too, dough was perfect and delicious.
will try just white sugar but might add vanilla extract ;D
regardless dough thickness was perfect and enjoyed.

I liked the recipe, but I don't know what I did. Either I didn't give my yeast enough time or it didn't raise well but it took forever to cook 1hr and 1/2 and still was not done. I had to take it off the pan and put on oven rack to get the bottom cooked. Someone help.

This recipe was so easy and good! I decided to make a double batch since we were making 2 pizzas. One I made following the directions exactly and the other I let the dough sit stretched and ready in the pan for about a 1/2 before assembling. If you like traditional crust go for the exact recipe but if you like the light and fluffy Greek style crust definitely go the 2nd route. Either way, it's a winner.
I made it and it was a success! Followed to a T with the addition of herbs & spices to the dough, because that's the way I roll... :) Will make again for sure.
I find that pizza dough is too wet and soft. I am not a fan.

After reading reviews, I added a bit more flour. I set it to rise, covered, on top of my heating pad on LOW, and it doubled in 30 minutes. It turned out great! Hubby LOVED it. I baked mine at 425 F. for 13 minutes - your results may vary so keep an eye until golden brown.

Great pizza dough recipe! I made it as written, but a hair less than 1 cup water. (I did use more flour when shaping the pie) You don't need a stand mixer - I started with a hand-mixer and then by hand. I made a small garlic white pizza on the grill to see how it went. Hubby - mehh (he said he didn't like the olive oil taste...so not the dough), but I thought it was great and offers a lot of variations. Can't wait to experiment with the dough:) Thank you for the receipe.

I decided to try this recipe instead of my usual pizza dough which takes hours to rise. I'm glad I did, the dough was tasty and so easy to make. Also, rather than using a pizza stone, try using an oiled cast iron skillet. I prefer my pizza on cast iron over my pizza stone anyway.
Very successful and easy recipe, the dough was so fluffy and just right
Way better than pre-made dough we buy at Safeway.

Turned out amazing! I followed the recipe to the word. Once rolled out I put garlic powder and basil on top to flavour and did a pre bake by putting a baking sheet in a cool oven while the oven preheats. Then I put just the dough on parchment paper on the pre heated sheet and baked it for 5 mins alone. Took it out, added my toppings and baked normally. Only thing I'd change is put a little more sauce on. Tried to be scant with it so the dough didn't get soggy but I could have gotten away with a little more. Crust came out perfectly
No changes. Will make again. Super easy!!!
this was my first attempt to make my own pizza dough, it was so easy and turned out so well!
Wonderful. It is a wet dough make sure you dump out on a well of flour
Needs about another half cup of flour at least. I added 1 tbs dried basil. Use cornmeal for the bottom when baking.

A big hit with the whole family. As many others have stated I added more flour as it wasn’t thick enough to work with. Once I had the consistency to my liking it was very easy to work with. Most importantly- it tasted amazing! We will make this again.
Everyone loves this crispy crust! I doubled it and only made 1 Pizza this time and had enough dough to freeze 1/2 and make a large cookie sheet size pizza and have enough frozen to do it again.
This is my family's favourite pizza dough recipe. I use it to make three decent-sized personal pizzas.
